articles.headline: On Reddit, Intimate Glimpses of Addicts in Thrall to Opioids
articles.snippet: Dispatches left on a now-banned forum show the role one of the world’s largest online communities played in facilitating access to drugs tied to a mounting toll.
articles.abstract: Dispatches left on a now-banned forum show the role one of the world’s largest online communities played in facilitating access to drugs tied to a mounting toll.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every day, thousands of people who are consumed by the nation’s opioid epidemic connect on the popular discussion website Reddit.
articles.byline: By Ellen Gabler and Rich Harris

articles.headline: U.S. Reopens Harley Settlement, Cutting Funds for Pollution Reduction Plan
articles.snippet: The Trump administration took $3 million off the motorcycle maker’s fine in a pollution case, applying a new policy barring benefits to third parties.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration took $3 million off the motorcycle maker’s fine in a pollution case, applying a new policy barring benefits to third parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year the United States government fined Harley-Davidson $15 million for selling devices that shut down its motorcycles’ emissions controls — and said part of that money would go toward a project to reduce pollution from wood-fired stoves.

articles.headline: Trump Aides, Seeking Leverage, Investigate Mueller’s Investigators
articles.snippet: In a sign of a looming showdown with the special counsel, presidential aides are looking for information to get investigators recused or justify firing him.
articles.abstract: In a sign of a looming showdown with the special counsel, presidential aides are looking for information to get investigators recused or justify firing him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s lawyers and aides are scouring the professional and political backgrounds of investigators hired by the special counsel Robert S. Mueller III, looking for conflicts of interest they could use to discredit the investigation — or even build a case to fire Mr. Mueller or get some members of his team recused, according to three people with knowledge of the research effort.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Maggie Haberman and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: The Ethics of Adjusting Your Assets to Qualify for Medicaid
articles.snippet: People who make themselves indigent to qualify for Medicaid are sometimes criticized. But consider the nuances of the situation, and other alternatives.
articles.abstract: People who make themselves indigent to qualify for Medicaid are sometimes criticized. But consider the nuances of the situation, and other alternatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: At any given moment, there is a large group of citizens who want nothing more than to make absolutely certain that they are impoverished enough to qualify for Medicaid sooner rather than later. Someday, you might be one of them.

articles.headline: As Self-Driving Cars Near, Washington Plays Catch-Up
articles.snippet: Congress is taking its first steps to regulate autonomous vehicles, as the technology moves closer to fruition.
articles.abstract: Congress is taking its first steps to regulate autonomous vehicles, as the technology moves closer to fruition.
articles.lead_paragraph: Self-driving cars are zooming at breakneck speed toward America’s roadways, and Washington is finally reaching for its seatbelt.

articles.headline: Sean Spicer Resigns as White House Press Secretary
articles.snippet: Mr. Spicer quit after telling President Trump he vehemently disagreed with the appointment of the financier Anthony Scaramucci as communications director.
articles.abstract: Mr. Spicer quit after telling President Trump he vehemently disagreed with the appointment of the financier Anthony Scaramucci as communications director.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sean Spicer, the White House press secretary, resigned Friday after telling President Trump he vehemently disagreed with his appointment of Anthony Scaramucci, a New York financier, as his new communications director.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman
